title: Daryl Braithwaite's NRL half-time TV broadcast ditched by Nine
text:
Viewers slammed Nine for failing to broadcast Daryl Braithwaite's NRL Grand Final half-time performance on television screens.

Taking to Twitter on Sunday, football fans labelled the network 'an absolute disgrace' after the 70-year-old sang his hit Horses at Sydney's ANZ Stadium.

'Is there anything more un-Australian than not showing us Daryl Braithwaite?' one viewer asked online.

Outrage: Viewers slammed Nine on Twitter for ditching Daryl Braithwaite's NRL Grand Final half-time TV broadcast on Sunday night. Pictured: Daryl Braithwaite

Vocal: 'Is there anything more un-Australian than not showing us Daryl Braithwaite?' one football fan asked

'Absolute disgrace that Channel Nine aren't showing Daryl Braithwaite at half-time. For God's sake - Horses is the second national anthem,' another posted.

One also asked rather bluntly: '#NRLGrandFinal why do you hate Daryl Braithwaite?'

While Christine Anu, 49, and Natalie Bassingthwaighte, 44, had their NRL Grand Final half-time performances broadcast on Nine, Daryl's failed to make the cut.

Daily Mail Australia has reached out to Channel Nine for comment.

Strong words: Another said it's an 'absolute disgrace' for Nine to ditch Daryl, 70, from the TV broadcast

Icon: Daryl delighted the crowd at Sydney's ANZ Stadium with his hit Horses

The decision to ditch Daryl from the TV broadcast comes after American pop band OneRepublic's lacklustre pre-game entertainment.

As the group chose to cover Beyoncé's 2008 hit Halo, viewers took to Twitter to criticise OneRepublic as well as Nine, for the odd song choice.

'Really? A Queen Bey funeral song pre-game?' One viewer commented online.

Criticism: Viewers also slammed NRL for their Grand Final pre-game entertainment on Twitter, as OneRepublic covered Beyoncé's 2008 hit Halo on Sunday night. Pictured: Ryan Tedder

Funeral song: 'Really? A Queen Bey funeral song pre-game?' one viewer asked on Twitter

'Why is Halo being sung as a cover at the NRL Grand Final?' another fan asked.

'OneRepublic's screaming cover of Beyoncé's Halo, while the choir try to cover up how bad he's singing, was the perfect choice to get the crowd pumped up for the #NRLGF well done NRL,' one wrote.

Some poked fun at the code's inability to secure Beyoncé for pre-game entertainment, sharing: 'When the #nrl wants to book Beyoncé but gets OneRepublic to perform Halo. Yuck.'

Harsh critique: One viewer suggested the staff of NRL should be 'sacked'

However it wasn't all negative, with select viewers praising OneRepublic for a stellar performance.

'Unpopular opinion on the Twitter verse right now, but OneRepublic actually doing a bl**dy good job,' one wrote. 'Not liking their music isn't a reason to slam them. Music is subjective.'

OneRepublic, comprising of lead vocalist Ryan Tedder, guitarists Zach Filkins and Drew Brown, basisst and cellist Brent Kutzle, drummer Eddie Fisher and keyboardist Brian Willett, took to the stage at Sydney's ANZ Stadium on Sunday night.

The band sung Beyoncé's Halo as well as their own hits, Counting Stars and Something I Need.

Hyped performance: OneRepublic, comprising of Ryan Tedder (pictured), Zach Filkins, Drew Brown, Brent Kutzle, Eddie Fisher and Brian Willett, took to the stage at Sydney's ANZ Stadium
description: Viewers slammed Nine for failing to broadcast Daryl Braithwaite's NRL Grand Final half-time performance on television screens.
authors: Kristy Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
